abstract.t: A potentially common misconception is that header 6LowPAN header compression is incompatible (or at least inefficient) with the notion of using addresses with sufficient entropy. This draft attempts to dispel that notion, and specifies how privacy addressing can be used on 6LoWPAN technologies, without additional overhead in data packets.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: RFC 6973 discusses privacy considerations for Internet protocols, and Section 5.2 in particular covers a number of privacy-specific threats. In the context of IPv6 address, Section 3 of provides further elaboration on the applicability of the privacy threats. When interface identifiers (IIDs) are generated without sufficient entropy, devices and users become vulnerable to the various threats discussed there, including correlation of activities over time, location tracking, address scanning, and device-specific vulnerability exploitation.

Interfaces identifiers formed from IEEE identifiers can have insufficient entropy unless the IEEE identifier itself has sufficient entropy, has enough (typically 64 or more) bits of entropy carried over into the IPv6 address to have a sufficiently large "anonymity set" as defined in . Furthermore, IEEE-identifier-based IIDs are also insufficient to prevent location tracking unless the IEEE identifier itself is different at each network location. This observation suggests that the privacy threats can be mitigated in either of two ways: either make sure the IEEE identifier contains 64 bits of entropy and is changed if a device moves to a different network, or else use an IPv6 address generation mechanism that is not IEEE-identifier-based.

Furthermore, to mitigate the threat of correlation of activities over time, specifies the notion of a "temporary" address to be used for sessions that should not be linkable to more permanent identifiers (such as a DNS name or stable hardware address). Such temporary addresses are appropriate for connections (typically locally-initiated outbound sessions) that do not use a stable identifier at a higher layer, such as a user name or hostname. Indeed, the default address selection rules now prefer temporary addresses by default for outgoing connections. A new temporary address is periodically (default is 1 day in xref target='RFC4941'/>) generated, which limits the threat of correlation of activies over time to that period. The address itself though may still be usable for existing long-lived connections (but not new connections) for some longer period (default is 1 week); this allows for not breaking application sessions, especially those that might be initiated shortly before a new temporary address is generated. This fact means that multiple temporary addresses will exist at the same time, one for new connections, and one or more (often up to 6, per the default periods) old ones for long-lived connections. This is in addition to zero or more "stable" addresses that might be used for connections that are linkable to more permanent identifiers such as DNS names or user names.

There has been some concern that such approaches would necessarily interfere with efficient header compression for IPv6 over IEEE 802.15.4-based networks , as it is important to keep data packets small on such networks. This document specifies how to use such addresses on these networks while avoiding extra overhead.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: This document uses the terminology defined in Section 3 of , including terms such as "(un)linkability" and "anonymity set".
The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: Details
section.t: RFC 6282 defines a method for deriving IIDs from the source and/or destination addresses in the encapsulation header. Unicast IPv6 addresses may be compressed to 64, 16, or 0 bits in the encoded IPv6 header.

A stable per-network random ID generation mechanism could be at layer 2 and that essentially becomes another variant way to implement if it's 64 bits of entropy. An IID generated from a random 16-bit address per Section 3.2.2 of is not sufficient to mitigate address scanning, and also does not sufficiently increase the size of the "anonymity set" defined in . The size of the address scan search space depends on the entropy in the IID. An adversary could also use statisical methods to determine the size of the L2 address space and thereby make some inference regarding the underlying technology on a given link.
However, either way it doesn't expand the packet if there's 0 address bits in the packet.
